It is important to note that the gun lobby is against the simple availability of smart guns, not a requirement that they be universally used or sold. They don't want anyone to have them at all, even if I, or you, were to choose one. This is freedom? This is individual choice? Why should they want to stop a safety device?

Of course, car manufacturers resisted seat belts and then air bags until they believed they could resist them no longer. Something is badly out of whack in our country when we can't have a safety device because a commercial enterprise believes it might harm its sales, don't ya think?

My car in high school had one of the first cross strapped seat belts in Pennsylvania. I was happy to have it. At the time, the state had a mandatory inspection system requiring a visit every six months (otherwise known as the "let's keep all the gas stations in business" law). So, when I went in for inspection, they cut my seat belt out. I asked why. Oh, you can't have that. It is not mandated.

It is true that once govt. gets its hands on us, it sometimes oversteps. Often, in fact. But we eventually got seat belts and enough air bags in cars that they might float if all inflated at once.

Can the gun lobby stop us from getting safety devices on guns? The answer right now is yes. They are one of the most powerful lobbies in DC and they've got millions of hunters and other gun lovers constantly worked up about gun rights. The rest of us? We don't count.

Doug Terry

My husband is a teacher and he has seen such programs offered to his district, which he has forwarded and recommended to his superintendent. I think they are definitely worth a trial.

His district has a pretty good rate of middle-class students going to college, but there are a lot of poorer students, and most of them don't go, or if they do, return within the first year. Anything that helps those families and those kids breach the problems facing potential first-generation college students is worth consideration and investigation. It can be a huge hurdle to cross, and many families have no idea how to help.

My husband is a first-generation college student himself, though from a time when it was much simpler to be one. That could be part of the reason for his empathy. The other, no doubt, and it's something I saw so much of as a teacher too, is that we see so much potential in these kids in our classes. It's a shame to see it wither in high school and after.

That's one problem with the VA bureaucracy - they start getting fixated on matters of timing and what's laughingly called 'efficiency', seeming to forget that they are dealing with human beings and not machines with interchangeable parts. And then there are some doctors and other therapists on staff at the hospitals who, frustrated with the fact that the longtime nurses know the patients - and how best to deal with them - a lot better than the docs, will try to get the upper hand by some sort of subterfuge. Take it from one who was a resident in psychiatry at a VA hospital and was, along with the other residents assigned to one staff doctor's unity, used to overturn the old system of granting patients privileges, against the advise of the nurses who were, by and large, infinitely more knowledgeable. You can imagine the disaster that ensued - and, of course, the residents were blamed, with the most blame going to those who were the most skeptical (Including yours truly). People aren't machines and 'standardised' treatment, especially for a serious problem that's different for each patient, is simply ridiculous. Especially when you try to rush things through without considering the consequences.

It's one thing to have unpopular values or poor judgment, but being entirely unencumbered by facts or generally-accepted principles of macroeconomics is quite another.

Just to illustrate, the availability of medical care has not been diminished because medical schools are producing too few physicians; last year the number of U.S. medical school graduates rose by 3% while the population grew by 1%. Shortages arise from the preference of physicians to practice in more densely-populated areas and to eschew primary care in favor of more lucrative specialties. To the poor and uninsured, it hardly has mattered whether good regular medical care was unavailable because there were no appropriate doctors available or because their services were unaffordable. The ACA now makes medical care affordable, and had Republicans not stood in the way, a single-payer system would have done it more efficiently.

And, by the way, Malthus was proven to be dead wrong long ago. Economic resources, certainly in America, are not so limited that it can't support more people. People and technology create resources and wealth from economic activity, when well-governed, as proven by the enormous growth in the U.S. population at the same time as GDP per-capita has increased.

A local college likely offers an introductory macroeconomics course, and you might enjoy learning the basic principles, as well as the means of acquiring reliable data.

There has never been a better reason for the Federal Reserve Bank to proceed with normalizing short rates against the backdrop of full employment and price stability domesitically than the specter of foreign central banks resorting to negative nominal interest rates designed to weaken their respective currencies.

Negative nominal interest rates create a sense of panic in the minds of fragile human beings. It undermines confidence. Serious people discuss the possibility of uncontrollable deflation with respect to fiat currencies.

The US economy is accelerating, near or at full employment, with price stability, and the only economy able to lift the globe out this transitory curiosity with fear of fiat currency uncontrollable deflation.

It has no basis in reality. It is a delusion.

The supply of fiat currency is unlimited and virtually costless to produce. Policy makers could monetize all national debts over night and no serious person would be discussing the uncontrollable threat of deflation.

I strongly believe the FRB has the fortitude to ignore the unfounded fears known to grip mankind and proceed to normalize short rates slowly and deliberately to alleviate the pressure on some central banks to take measures that further undermine the confidence of those with less understanding of markets.

The nation has been perfectly set up for the results we see. 30 years of increased productivity with none of the benefits going to labor. All of the benefits are going to shareholders and managers. Yet if globalization tamps down workers' wages, why does it not tamp down management and owners' incomes and benefits? If tech change replaces human labor, why does it not also replace bloated management, too? We are simply seeing the results of a standard class conflict, with the super-manager/owner class (call it the 1% if you wish) winning the big battles because they can better buy legislators and so legislation that creates and protects their perks—carried interest, taxpayer bailouts, corporate tax schemes at the state level, ad nauseum. I am sure that the enthusiasts would not like that. But it would be a good safety mechanism for the rest of us from the insane members of our society who believe they need quick access to deadly force.
